urn:contentItem:5WF7-BYG1-DY0W-43F3-00000-00Facebook Is In The Crosshairs Right Now For The Alleged Misuse Of Information, Fifty Million Facebook Data Were Harvested Without Their Permission; Lawmakers Are Demanding An Investigation of Facebook; Tech Stocks Are Down Today As It Also Sympathizes With Facebook's Decline; E.U. Also Threatened To Slap A Whopping 3 Percent Tax On All U.S. Tech Company Sales As Well; Lawmakers On Both Sides Of The Aisle Have Reacted On The Firing Of FBI Deputy Director Andrew Mccabe; Los Alamitos County In Southern California Is Standing Up, Saying They Want To Opt Out Of California Sanctuary Laws That Restrict Cooperation Between Local Police And Federal Immigration; Uber Pulls Out Its Program From Self-Driving Vehicle After a Woman Died Last Night When a Robot Car Struck and Killed Her in Tempe, Arizona; Al Sharpton's National Action Network, Black Lives Matter, and the New Black Panther Party are Organizing a Protest in Support of and in Defense of Louis Farrakhan; Hillary Clinton Posted on Facebook a Lengthy Non-Apology Statement Trying to Defend Her Controversial Comments About the Trump Voters and Why She Lost the Race2018-03-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:46:16ZLexisNexisFacebook Is In The Crosshairs Right Now For The Alleged Misuse Of Information, Fifty Million Facebook Data Were Harvested Without Their Permission; Lawmakers Are Demanding An Investigation of Facebook; Tech Stocks Are Down Today As It Also Sympathizes With Facebook's Decline; E.U. Also Threatened To Slap A Whopping 3 Percent Tax On All U.S. Tech Company Sales As Well; Lawmakers On Both Sides Of The Aisle Have Reacted On The Firing Of FBI Deputy Director Andrew Mccabe; Los Alamitos County In Southern California Is Standing Up, Saying They Want To Opt Out Of California Sanctuary Laws That Restrict Cooperation Between Local Police And Federal Immigration; Uber Pulls Out Its Program From Self-Driving Vehicle After a Woman Died Last Night When a Robot Car Struck and Killed Her in Tempe, Arizona; Al Sharpton's National Action Network, Black Lives Matter, and the New Black Panther Party are Organizing a Protest in Support of and in Defense of Louis Farrakhan; Hillary Clinton Posted on Facebook a Lengthy Non-Apology Statement Trying to Defend Her Controversial Comments About the Trump Voters and Why She Lost the RaceLanhamFULL TEXT

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

NEIL CAVUTO, FOX NEWS HOST: Have you been seeing what's going on with Facebook. This industry darling led the market up last year and through much of this year quite a different take today.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Cambridge Analytica was able to can collect the data from 50 million people's profiles without permission. In the U.S., in Europe, in the U.K. are calling for investigations Facebook is in the crosshairs.

GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS REPORTER: Social media companies are trading lower today. I guess in sympathy. Twitter, Snap, Google all lower.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: People are starting to grow tired of social media.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes, yes.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Facebook basically can't be escape. This is something that as far --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Everybody in their mother now saying we are going to investigate.

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX NEWS HOST: Facebook privacy hitting markets really hard today. Facebook having its worst day in five and half years. The Dow also are down nearly 500 points at session lows at tech is drag down in sympathy. The NASDAQ slid nearly 2 percent. Facebook dragging tech stock lower.

This, after reports that the personal Facebook data of an estimated 50 million people were harvested without their permission for political ad. You will not believe what we found that Facebook has on you. One hundred separate bits of information. We're going to show you what Facebook is collecting about you. E.U. also threatening a whopping 3 percent tax on tech company sales as well.

And this now breaking. The Connecticut Attorney General's office is initiating an inquiry into Facebook data policy after that report.

Also tonight, could Andrew McCabe, the fired former FBI deputy director incriminate the fired FBI James Comey, not just release to the media but for also lying to Congress. We got the sound and the debate coming up. We're on it.

And a tiny California town now defiantly fighting back against California sanctuary policy, saying it will instead follow their sworn oath to defend the Constitution and uphold immigration laws. It's the City of Los Alamitos it's voted tonight to not be a sanctuary city. It faces the threat of lawsuits in California condemnation as well. The mayor of that town here to talk about the fight.

Plus, driverless robot cars, now they were supposed to reduce traffic fatalities by eliminating human error. But now a robot car from ridesharing company Uber has killed a pedestrian in Arizona. It happened last night. So what will happen to the robot revolution? That's now in the works of a slew of auto companies like Tesla, G.M. Ford and also Silicon Valley. We're bringing an expert to weigh in.

Tonight, an all-guest lineup. Economist Ben Stein, former special assistant to President Trump, Marc Lotter, legal eagle Harvard Law professor Alan Dershowitz, the Federalist Britt McHenry, all here all tonight.

Politics, money, we got you covered. I'm Elizabeth McDonald. Risk and Reward starts right now.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARK ZUCKERBERG, CEO, FACEBOOK: I wish I could tell you that we're going to be able to stop all interference but that just wouldn't be realistic. There will always be bad actors in the world and we can't prevent all governments from all interference. But we can make it harder. We can make it much harder and that's what we're going to focus on doing.

We won't catch everyone immediately but we can make it harder to try to determine (Ph).

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: The Dow down 335 points closing to that 24,610. The NASDAQ taking hits, that was down as well. Facebook stocks ending more than 6 percent down or 12 points lower after suspending a political analysis firm Cambridge Analytics after reports that the research firm harvested personal Facebook data on 270,000 Facebook users without their permission.

Now you can't Facebook friends and family. The breach may affect an estimated 50 million people. It's being Facebook Equifax breach. The research firm also reportedly told Facebook it did delete the user info when it did not. Pretty scary stuff.

There's actually a really long list of things that Facebook knows about you. We counted a hundred different things. For example, where you live, your age, your education, income, net worth, your wedding anniversary birthday whether you recently moved.

If you're in a long-distance relationship, whether you are conservative or liberal, whether you like would you're likely to buy your next car, how many workers your company has, whether you carry a credit card balance. The time of year your household shops and the most types of vacations you take, the pets you have, and so on, and so on, and so on, more and more and more.

But first, Lori Rothman on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange on the market drop after reports of this privacy breach at Facebook. You know, Lori, Facebook faces a threat of federal fines. The tech sector also dropping after the E.U. threaten to slap U.S. tech companies with a 3 percent tax of sales and revenues. Wow, Lori.

LORI ROTHMAN, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: One, two punch against the tech sector today and that just drag down the broad market. We had the Dow closing down 335 points today, believe it or not that's well, well more than a hundred points off the session low for the Dow. Down now negative temperature territory for 2018.

The S&P and the NASDAQ didn't fare much better. The NASDAQ was the worst in the benchmark three but it's still holding up for the year. There you see on your screen the NASDAQ fell 137 points blame Facebook.

But here is the thing that's got everyone here on Wall Street thinking. If Facebook is misusing customer data, user data, well, all of these tech companies use our data. They mine our data. We plug our data in. How do they get it, what do they do with it when they have it. And really how do they protect every day users.

So, a lot of the big tech company CEO's have been called upon by both Democrats and Republicans to testify about that. And then you mention this potential tax 3 percent by the E.U. on the tech company revenue.

So the good times may be over for tech. That was the thinking and the concern today on Wall Street, obviously nothing for sure on that front but any news of that degree again. Again, a one-two punch. The Facebook news and then the tax. My goodness. You're going to have some trouble.

And then of course you can talk about the ongoing trade and tariff controversy as well. So we did have a broad base rally, it wasn't just technology. All 10 S&P sectors were in the red today.

We do want to bring you up-to-date on some mergers, merger Monday. Well, actually this one in particular is going nowhere. I'm talking about AT&T and Time Warner shares both down in excess of 1 percent. AT&T tried today to get a judge to throw out evidence. It seems to show its $85 billion acquisition of Time Warner is bad for consumers and competition.

Now the Justice Department as you know did file a lawsuit back in November to stop this combination opening arguments in this case are still scheduled to begin on Wednesday. We're following it. Liz, back to you.

MACDONALD: Good to see you, Lori. Thank you so much.

ROTHMAN: Thank you.

MACDONALD: Now this firm that's denying claims of abusing and have taking without consent the data of millions of Facebook users. That's called Cambridge Analytics. This as Facebook hired a digital forensic firm to do an audit of Cambridge Analytica systems.

Politicians now pressuring Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg for answers on what's going on. The word is Mark Zuckerberg may have to testify before Congress. Remember he has political leanings.

Gerri Willis has more. Gerri?

WILLIS: Hi, Liz. That's right. You know, just the latest on the latest on this incredibly fast moving story. Here's what Facebook had to say about hiring a digital forensics firm. Listen to this. "We hired a digital forensics firm, Stroz Friedberg to conduct a comprehensive audit, they say, of Cambridge Analytica. Cambridge Analytica has agreed to comply and afford the firm complete access to their servers and systems."

So that's a move forward here I supposed for Facebook. The other thing that's going on and this again, this is just out moments ago. Connecticut is launching, the attorney general there, a probe into what's gone on with Facebook. So that's something new. Reaction was swift and then you have on two continents with both the E.U. and the Massachusetts Attorney General Maura Healey launching probes. Yet Facebook says the situation is unlike data breaches, breaches that have plagued American companies.

For years now, here's what Facebook said. The claim that this is data breach is completely false. People knowingly provided their information. No systems were infiltrated. No passwords or sensitive pieces of information. We're still and or hack. At issues that hundreds of thousands of a Facebook users were paid to download to take a personality test and agreed to have their data collected, they agreed to it. The app was called this is your digital life.

Facebook later change its policy and didn't allow this kind of scraping to be done. But Cambridge had retained access to the data as late as 2015. Cambridge now says no info from the company that provided the data was used in the 2016 election. Cambridge Analytica fully complies with Facebook terms of service.

And back to you, Liz.

MACDONALD: Yes. Wow, what a story, Gerri. Thank you so much for coming on. We really appreciate it.

Now remember Mark Zuckerberg's New Year's resolution. He vowed to fix Facebook and to correct persistent problems that had dogged the networks. Let's take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ZUCKERBERG: Now we're going to explore ways that we can share more information about anyone attempting to interfere with elections. We are working proactively to strengthen the democratic process. Beyond pushing back against threats we will also create more services to protect our community while engaging in political discourse.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Let's bring in the economist and author of "The Capitalist Code" Ben Stein. You know, Ben, this is kind of making people unsettled and uncomfortable. It's astonishing how much information Facebook has on you and also your kids.

BEN STEIN, ECONOMIST: It is astonishing in a way but it doesn't really affect Facebook as an investment. I mean, Facebook is still a very powerful company filling an enormously large niche and void in the American life. Facebook in a way has become an almost spiritual guide to human companionship and human fellowship. And almost spiritual guide and antidote to human loneliness.

I don't think that one day's notes about somebody misusing data or maybe not using data are going to change that. I can still consider stocks a fantastically important part of anyone's portfolio.

MACDONALD: Yes, I know what you mean that people could connect with their family and their friends. But the fact remains that this looks like Facebook's equivalent of the Equifax breach.

If info is going to help political campaigns the allegation was the Trump campaign benefit. Also a former Obama campaign staffer candidly admits, Ben, that Facebook let the Obama campaign quote, "improperly access Facebook user dater -- data. The staffer, her name is Carol Davidson. She said this. "Facebook was surprised we were able to suck out the whole social graph, but they did not stop us once they realized that what we were doing. They came to office in the days after the election recruiting and were very candid that they let us do things they would not have allowed someone else to do because they were on our side."

That was back in 2012. I mean, that's six years ago, Ben. Now Facebook is returning itself as sort of discomforted by all thing, all this. But you know, that was Obama's campaign. We don't want to get too political about this. But what is going on with Silicon Valley companies letting people access data.

STEIN: Well, what's going on is that it's going to, it's bound to happen. The internet is not a closed system. The internet is a system that people can get into, a very clever people can get into even if it's tightly sealed up. We know that the Russians and the Chinese are able to get into it even if we think it's sealed tightly as a drum.

What I want to go after is, is it still a good investment. And I say it's still is a very good investment. And the fact that people are upset about their data being accessed is too bad. And it's upsetting. And we don't want it to happen. And we want people's privacy to be respected. But we also want to be realistic about this. How is it possibly going to affect their earnings unless there's absolutely stupendous fine. I think --

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: Yes. But you know, they're so, you know, they have so much information, Ben, they could pretty much accurately predict what kind of car you are going to buy, what kind of house you're going to buy, and where your kids are going to college.

STEIN: Absolutely.

MACDONALD: I'm not sure Americans realize how much Facebook knows about them.

STEIN: I'm not sure they do either, but I'm going to what the show is about, what you are wonderfully about in Fox Business is about which is making money. And that is I don't think anything we've learned in the last several days is going to affect whether or not Facebook is going to --

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: All right. Ben, stay on that for a second. Hang on one second. Because some Americans want Facebook fined, hit with penalties for its role in the Russian meddling during the election.

Remember, you and I were talking about this, Ben, how Russian internet trolls loaded Facebook up with fake news. Even fake Facebook Russia-backed political rallies. Should Facebook be fined for that?

STEIN: Maybe they should be and maybe they shouldn't be. I don't think the Russia Trump collusion has improved to that any meaningful effect on the campaign at all on way or the other. And I think the more they push that the more they find that there's nothing at the end of the string. You can only push the string so far.

I'm not worried about that Russia Trump collusion because I don't it ever happen. If it did happened, it happen as such a minor scale that hardly matters at all. What I'm concerned about is this, is it still a good business to be in a business of providing communication for hundreds of millions and billions of people all around the world who would otherwise be sitting on lonely twiddling their thumbs.

And I think they're still a very, very good business. And the fact that they can access all of this information about all kinds of people in America or in Mexico or in Cuba or probably not Cuba, or anywhere tells us that this is still a very, very strong investment.

MACDONALD: OK.

STEIN: This stick on me that it's just an absolutely a house on fire in terms of power and I don't think there's going to be any stopping short of abolishing it. I don't anyone dares to abolish them.

MACDONALD: All right. Ben Stein, good to see you. Thank you so much for coming on.

STEIN: It's an honor as always.

MACDONALD: Same here. It appears to be the first driverless, well, there was a driver but this is on automatic mode. It was on robot mode. A robot car killed somebody in Tempe, Arizona. Ridesharing company Uber that it was this car it now stopped its self-driving car program. An Arizona woman struck and killed by one of the robot vehicles. It happened last night around 10 o'clock.

Coming up, we're bringing in an expert who is saying who is responsible. We're going to get to the bottom on who's to blame and who could face liability. Is it the car company Uber or is it the software.

Also this. One tiny Southern California town now sitting up in defiance to the big and powerful in the sanctuary state. It's the town of Los Alamitos in Orange County. It wants to opt out of California's sanctuary laws. The mayor of that town here to talk about it.

But first, could Andrew McCabe the fired former FBI deputy director, could he incriminate the fired FBI former Director James Comey, not just release to the media but for also for lying to Congress. We got the sound, we're going to drill into this debate, coming up next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. ANGUS KING (I), MAINE: It just seem mean-spirited to come down on a guy within 48 hours of his scheduled retirement. It was clearly rushed and I think there are questions about that and whether the administration was putting pressure on the Justice Department to take this action.

SEN. JEFF FLAKE (R), ARIZONA: It was a horrible day for democracy. To have firings like this happening at the top from the president and the attorney general does not speak well for what's going on.

SEN. MARCO RUBIO (R), FLORIDA: I don't like it happened. He should have been allowed to finish through the weekend.

REP. ADAM SCHIFF (D), CALIFORNIA: You know, his firing may be justified, there's no way for us to know at this point. But though it may have been justified it can also be tainted.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: A number of congressmen and senators up and arms of the firing of FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe. It was a recommendation from the FBI's own Office of Professional Responsibility they said yes, fire him.

Republican Congressman Trey Gowdy reminding everyone it was McCabe's fault.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. TREY GOWDY (R), SOUTH CAROLINA: Andy McCabe was undercut his credibility all by himself. he didn't any help doing that and I thought it richly ironic that he is lamenting that those are attacking the FBI when he himself does the exact same thing. It was the FBI who said he made an unauthorized disclosure and then a lied about it.

That wasn't President Trump, it wasn't me, it wasn't the crazy House Republicans. It was his own fellow FBI agents the said he leaked and then lied about it. So if he's got credibility issues he need look no further than himself.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Joining me now former special assistant to Present Trump, Marc Lotter. Marc, what's your take on McCabe's firing?

MARC LOTTER, FORMER ASSISTANT TO PRESIDENT TRUMP: I think it sounds it was completely justified. You had an inspector general report the Office of Professional Responsibility and then the senior career official at the department all made these recommendations so that's what the attorney general acted on.

And I think what we're seeing right now is a case of many other Democrats and some of their friends in the mainstream media are trying to have it both ways. When someone pleads guilty to lying to investigators that are on the Republican side it's breaking news and it's proof that something is amiss except when someone is accused of doing the same thing to federal officials on the other side will then they're just trying to play "Cry Me a River," so they can't have it both ways.

MACDONALD: Yes. People go to prison for misleading the FBI. I mean, McCabe is accused of misleading Justice Department investigating -- in investigators about his leaking of sensitive information to Wall Street Journal reporter about the FBI's investigation of pay to play at the Clinton Foundation while Hillary Clinton was secretary of state.

McCabe now says, Marc, that he had authority to quote share that information with the media and Director James Comey knew about that. But Marc, the issue is really covering up the leak, right? So is there anything wrong with the way he was fired?

LOTTER: Well, obviously the inspector general report which we have not seen yet does suggest that there were some sort of improprieties in the way he was conducting his business. And when you follow that on with the Office of professional Responsibility and the senior career official in the department all making me this conclusion then something there is amiss and it may just be lying or misleading investigators or maybe something more to it.

But we got to be honest here. We can't -- we cannot, as a country, tolerate any kind of impropriety when it comes to members of law enforcement at any level. We place our trust in them to act honorably within the bounds of their oath. If they don't, we need to get to that right away.

MACDONALD: You know, former FBI Director James Comey is coming out with his book right at the same time this I.G. report is coming up from the Justice Department. But here's the problem for James Comey. The firing of Andrew McCabe may cause problems for James Comey.

Remember when Comey said this under oath last year.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Director Comey, have you ever been an anonymous source in news reports about matters relating to the Trump investigation or the Clinton investigation?

JAMES COMEY, FORMER UNITED STATES FBI DIRECTOR: Never.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Question 21 relatively related. Have you ever authorize someone else at the FBI to be an anonymous source is news reports about the Trump investigation or the Clinton investigation?

COMEY: No.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: OK. So Comey said under oath he never was a source of the media nor authorize any FBI officials to talk to the media. But look at this. An Andrew McCabe's statement after getting fired he wrote this. "The I.G. investigation is focused on information I chose to share with a reporter who my public affairs officer and legal counselor. As Deputy Director, I was one of only a few people who had the authority to do that. It was not a secret place, it took place, and others including the director, meaning James Comey were aware of the interaction with the reporter.

So Marc, did you catch that. The director meaning Comey was aware. So what -- how does that stuck up with Comey saying what he said to Congress last year about he didn't allow -- he never allow any of this.

LOTTER: Clearly they've got contradicting stories and I think this is why so many Republicans are saying we need another special investigator to look at the way the FBI's conducted itself in a very small group at the highest levels. We cannot have these inconsistencies if partisanship if things were taking place in the Clinton investigation that was not aboveboard, that was not inconsistent -- that was not consistent with their oath then when you look into it.

And right now as you pointed out we see it happening where they are contradicting each other and who said what and when.

MACDONALD: Marc Lotter, great to see you. Thanks for coming on.

LOTTER: Thanks, Liz.

MACDONALD: Breaking news. Fox News confirming that the president is hiring a new legal defense team to official to help in dealing with the special counsel's Russia probe. Former Bush U.S. attorney Joseph DiGenova will join President Trump's legal team. He has previously suggested that the Justice Department and FBI framed the president. The edition that Mr. DiGenova as the first change with legal teams since last summer.

Next up, one tiny Southern California it is standing up in defiance to the big and the powerful in the sanctuary state of California. It's Los Alamitos in Orange County. It wants to opt out of California sanctuary laws that restrict cooperation between local police and federal immigration. They are saying in Los Alamitos that swore an oath to uphold the Constitution and what state is asking them to do is violating that oath.

We're bringing the mayor of that town Troy Edgar to speak out after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: One tiny Southern California town now standing up in defiance to being powerful in the state of California. Los Alamitos wants to opt out of California sanctuary laws that restrict cooperation between local police and federal immigration agents.

Council members in the city now say they have sworn an oath to uphold the Constitution and that California so-called sanctuary laws undercuts that oath as well as federal law.

Let's bring in the mayor Los Alamitos, he's Troy Edgar. Good to see you, mayor.

TROY EDGAR, MAYOR, LOST ALAMITOS, CALIFORNIA: Hi, Liz. How are you doing?

MACDONALD: Thanks for coming on. Can you spell out this fight and what officials in your town are saying because we've got university professors in California saying, you know what, you're right in the crosshairs of lawsuits.

EDGAR: Yes. You know, this is a small city in Southern California what we're really trying to do is we're telling the state is, look, at this point, you know, we are conflicted with the U.S. Constitution and Los Alamitos we firmly believe that the U.S. Constitution is the supreme law of the land and that the SP 54 sanctuary law is in conflict. And at this point we're going to vote tonight to see if we will exempt ourselves from that.

MACDONALD: You know, we've got -- we've run on the show, mayor, sheriffs in California who are twisted into pretzel knots trying to abide by the Constitution the federal law and what the state is telling them to do.

What I would like you know and I think the viewer wants to have you spoken to other mayors in California, are there other cities like yours who do not want to be part of the sanctuary state policies?

EDGAR: Yes, there's a lot of mayors in California that don't want to be a part of it, but you know it's a really tough situation because in our state lot of this legislation comes out of Sacramento just seems disconnected that they're not attached. You know, when you're mayor of a small town immediately your constituents tell you how they feel where they're at and, you know, you're going to find out that evening in the grocery store whether you're doing a good job or not.

And I think a lot of the stuff is going on Sacramento people this constantly saying to all of us on the council what is going on.

MACDONALD: Have you experienced crime from illegal immigrants in your town?

EDGAR: No, I would say that we don't have a significant amount of crime problems with illegal immigrants. I think for us this is a constitutional issue that we're looking at and saying look, we are consistently being held to different standards by the state. A lot of them unfunded this is another one where they pass a law and now they're asking us to choose between the U.S. Constitution and the state Constitution.

MACDONALD: Yes.

EDGAR: And I think based on our oath, you now, many of us want to stay and focus on the U.S. Constitution.

MACDONALD: You know, we're wondering if your vote tonight will set up a chain reaction. Which other mayors are telling you that they agree with you and want to opt out? What are the mayors of what town?

EDGAR: Well, you know what, I think right now I think a lot of the mayors are going to wait and see and how this is going to go.

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: But do you know they found?

EDGAR: I do. But I I want to give them an opportunity to bring this upon themselves and I've also talked to a different staff and city attorneys at different city specially the elected city attorneys that the definitely have a perspective on which direction they or their city may want to go.

MACDONALD: Mayor, we have Sheriff Margaret Mims, she's in Fresno, California. She's been speaking out against California sanctuary laws. I'd like your reaction to what the sheriff said. Let's take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARGARET MIMS, SHERIFF, FRESNO COUNTY: We need to stop vilifying our hard- working ICE agents and our federal law enforcement partners. They are doing their jobs. Law enforcement has to enforce the law, teachers have to teach, and preachers have to preach and we're not going to apologize any of us for doing our jobs.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: So, mayor, do you hear from your local law enforcement the same thing that the sheriff just said?

EDGAR: You know what, I think that there is kind of two different jurisdictions. The sheriff definitely deals with the county, Orange County level and at L.A. County for us, but you know, the sheriff is little bit different than the police chief.

And so, within our cities we all have police chiefs and we across the different cities so have a lot of different types of things that are going on. And I think tonight what we will hear --

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: But are your cops upset about it, are your cops upset about two different standards they are dealing with?

EDGAR: Now. You know what, I think at this point it's probably more the counsel, you know, Mayor Pro Tem Kusumot has been really focused on this and him and I together really want to kind of bring this up and have an open discussion with the city council and start bringing stuff into this on more formal basis.

MACDONALD: Mayor Troy Edgar of Los Alamitos standing up in defiance against California laws. Good to see you, mayor. Thanks you so much for coming on.

EDGAR: Thank you, Liz.

MACDONALD: Now -- you, too. It appears to be the first driverless car fatality on a public road it involved ridesharing company Uber. It has now stop its self driving robot car program after a woman in Tempe, Arizona was struck and killed by one of its robots cars.

Coming up, an attorney on who could be responsible, is it Uber or is it the software?

But first, forget about distancing themselves. Reverend Al Sharpton is now saying we are going to do a protest in support and in defense of anti- Semite and racist Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan.

We're bringing on Harvard law professor Alan Dershowitz to react after this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LOUIS FARRAKHAN, LEADER, NATION OF ISLAM: Hitler was a very great man. The Satanic Jews. White folks are going down.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

FARRAKHAN: Hear the Jews they don't like Farrakhan so they call me Hitler. That's a good name. Hitler was a very great man.

Your country has been taken from you by the synagogue of Satan. The Satanic Jews. White folks are going down.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Black activist groups including Al Sharpton's national action network also Black Lives Matters -- matter and the New Black Panther Party now organizing a protest in support of and in defense of the controversial leader of the Nation of Islam, Louis Farrakhan. The groups are protesting a congressional resolution condemning Farrakhan.

With me now Harvard law Professor Alan Dershowitz. First of all, Alan, professor, rather, there are some other comments made by Farrakhan. Here's one of them. The Jews talk about never again. You cannot say never again to God because when he puts you in the oven you're in one indeed.

He also said the Jews of control over those agency -- agency of the government. He also said this. When a woman does not know how to cook and the right foods to cook she's preparing death for herself, her husband and her children.

You know, Professor, Democrats like Maxine Waters, Al Green, Keith Ellison, they also have links to Farrakhan. What's going on here?

ALAN DERSHOWITZ, PROFESSOR, HARVARD LAW SCHOOL: Well, first of all, Farrakhan is not only an anti-Semite, he's anti-white, he's anti-woman, he's anti-gay. He's anti everything decent in this country and when you get bigots supporting him and people like Al Sharpton was has his own history of anti-Semitism.

Black Lives Matter which singled out only Israel called genocide to an apartheid country which was anti-Semitic as well. What we have in this country as people who believe in an affirmative action program for racism for African Americans. That if you're an African-American you can get away with supporting anti-Semitism, anti-gay, anti-white --

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: But wait a minute, wait, wait, wait. Because you know, Trump is being accused of racism but now we've got an MSNBC host Al Sharpton defending this anti, you know, this anti-Semite, this racist anti-gay individual. I don't understand why more people are not condemning Farrakhan including Democrats.

DERSHOWITZ: Well, the Democrats should condemn him, the women's movement should condemn him, gay rights movement should condemn him, everybody should condemn him. And I don't never have understood why Al Sharpton was a history of anti-Semitism, the history about lying and falsely accusing people of crime should be on the major network.

If you had a white person who is equivalently racist against blacks and who defended David Duke he would never ever get on the air on a national network. And yet, we have affirmative action for black races and that's just unjustified. We have zero tolerance for bigotry, racism, and anti- Semitism and under the standard at zero-tolerance are not only doesn't Farrakhan satisfy it but neither does Sharpton, neither does Black Lives Matter, and neither to the congressmen who were now standing in support of a big anti-Semite.

Imagine if Republican congressmen standing in support of David Duke and Farrakhan is much, much, much more dangerous than David Duke. Because Farrakhan has the support of hundreds of thousands of African-Americans. What's my source to that? My source to that is Sharpton who says that he has massive support in the African-American community.

David Duke doesn't have any support and so we should not have a double standard. And Democrats and all decent people should come out not only against Farrakhan but any congressperson who supports Farrakhan.

MACDONALD: Yes, so let's get to one of those congressmen, professor. It's Democrat Congressman of Illinois, he's Danny Davis. He tried to clarify his position, he and his praise. Danny Davis has praise Farrakhan and has met with Farrakhan.

Here's what he saying now. Quote, "I disagree with Minister Farrakhan in terms of white people being devils and Jewish people being Satanic. But I also protect his right as a free individual to say and do whatever he wants to do. I think he does outstanding things for, especially blacks who are unsure about themselves and people who've been in prison."

Your reaction to that.

DERSHOWITZ: People said the same thing about Adolf Hitler that he did good things for the German people. You cannot justify this kind of bigotry by saying that he also does some decent things. And I think it's a scandal that the Democratic Party and liberals and the New York Times lets a black bigots off the hook. Only a text to bigotry on the right.

Today the danger of bigotry is far greater from the hard left, from the African-American community from the Muslim community, from many other communities which tolerated (AUDIO GAP) bigotry than it is from the right. Look, anti-Semitism was wrong for both the right and the left. We all condemn it from the right, let's join together to condemn it from the left regardless of the race of the person behind it.

MACDONALD: Professor Alan Dershowitz, we love having you on. Come back soon, sir.

DERSHOWITZ: Any time. Thank you.

MACDONALD: All right. The robot cars are supposed to stop fatalities. But now it appears to be the first death caused by the robot car in a public road. Ridesharing company Uber stopping its self-driving car program after a woman in Arizona was struck and killed by one of its robot cars last night.

We're bringing in an attorney on what this means for the car industry and Silicon Valley.

But first, Hillary Clinton now backtracking now her none-apologize -- apology after implying last week that women who cast a ballot who voted for Trump for this all due to pressure from their husbands.

My all-female power panel is here to react after this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. DICK DURBIN (D), ILLINOIS: It's not helpful at all. And in fact, my friend Hillary Clinton is wrong.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

HILLARY CLINTON, FORMER UNITED STATES PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: We do not do well with white men and we don't do well with married white women. And part of that is a -- an identification with the Republican Party and a sort of ongoing pressure to vote the way that your husband, your boss, your son, whoever believes you should.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Hillary Clinton putting up a lengthy 861-word non-apology on Facebook, trying to defend and explain her controversial comments about the Trump campaign. It's called backwards that the state that didn't vote for her are not optimistic, diverse or dynamic, and that white women vote like their husband. She made those comments a week and a half ago in India.

But now Hillary Clinton says this. "I also mentioned something in passing that's got a lot of attention." She's saying now that she said in passing, "that there is anecdotal level and some research to suggest that women are unfortunately more swayed by men than the other way around. As much as I hate the possibility and hate saying it, it's not that crazy when you think about our ongoing struggle to reach the gender balance even within the same household.

I understand how some of what I said upset people and can be misinterpreted. I mean, meant no disrespect to any individual or group. I want to look to the future not just anybody."

With me now, the Federalist, Britt McHenry, and Democrat strategist, Danielle McLaughlin. Britt, are you satisfied what is not apology. I mean, why is Hillary even bringing up these things, why get into it?

BRITT MCHENRY, CONTRIBUTOR, THE FEDERALIST: Absolutely not. Hillary Clinton is like that relative, that strange relative that comes to family gatherings and you just know that she's just going to say something patronizing and offensive which she did.

Donald Trump 52 percent of white women votes, so she's right about that, 61 percent of white women without college degree. So in her non-apology she is trying to say that those white women anyone watching this program right now don't have gender equality in their household. It's ridiculous. And she can't get out of her own way.

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: And that they can't think for themselves --

MCHENRY: Exactly.

MACDONALD: -- they just follow what their husbands are doing. OK. Danielle, Democrat Senate Minority Whip Dick Durbin speaking out against Clinton's comment. Let's listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DURBIN: It's not helpful at all. And in fact, my friend Hillary Clinton is wrong. Thirty percent of the people who voted for Donald Trump had voted for President Obama. Why? The same people who look for change with President Obama thought wasn't enough for us, their personal lives were concerned and they supported Donald Trump.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: How come more Democrats, Danielle are not joining Dick Durbin and condemning comments like Hillary made?

DANIELLE MCLAUGHLIN, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: Well, I think because Dick Durbin is right. You know, I don't think that what she said on that face --

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: But how come more Democrats -- how come more Democrats are not stepping out and saying you know what, Hillary, you're wrong?

MCLAUGHLIN: Well, I think plenty have in all honesty and they don't because they probably wants to draw much attention to it.

MACDONALD: Who?

MCLAUGHLIN: But I will give the person credit for apologizing.

MACDONALD: Who besides Dick Durbin has stepped up?

MCLAUGHLIN: There have been a number of Democrats, there have been a number of people on television who have said this as well.

MACDONALD: Who?

MCLAUGHLIN: I can name for you, Liz.

MACDONALD: OK. Go ahead.

MCLAUGHLIN: I mean, this is clearly something that you would never say and shouldn't even say. But you know what? I give her credit for apologizing. We have a president who has insulted many number of people.

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: It wasn't an apology. Have you read it? Have you read it? Danielle, have you read it? It was a non-apology.

MCLAUGHLIN: And she said very much that --

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: She didn't say she was sorry anywhere in that Facebook post.

MCLAUGHLIN: Well, I mean, she said I mean I meant no disrespect. She did not meant to hurt people or harm people that as far more that Donald Trump has ever said when he talked about John McCain or Judge Curiel --

MACDONALD: Understood. But we're talking about -- understood. I get what you're saying. H has said an extraordinary inflammatory things.

MCLAUGHLIN: Right.

MACDONALD: We get that and we've covered it here on the show.

MCLAUGHLIN: I know --

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: We're talking about Hillary right now. Britt, she's no apology there.

MCHENRY: There's no apology. And if Democrats want success they need more moderate Democrats like we saw with Conor Lamb who won in a congressional district that won by 20 points for Trump in Trump's favor in 2016. That's going to send their message not that I particularly wanted to go over the Democrats instead of this identity politics and just offensive rhetoric from Hillary Clinton.

MACDONALD: Britt and Danielle, thank you so much for coming on. I really appreciate it.

MCHENRY: Thank you.

MACDONALD: Breaking news. Washington Post reporting that President Trump is preparing by this Friday to hit China with tariffs on $60 billion worth of goods that would double the what was earlier thought to be 30 billion, now it's going to 60 billion. It could be 100 different types of products hit with tariffs by this Friday.

This amid the escalation of trade tensions is going to four anonymous senior administration officials. We're staying on that story for you.

Now it appears to be the first robot car death on a public road. Ridesharing company Uber stopping its self-driving car program after a woman in Arizona was struck and killed by one of its robot vehicle.

Attorney Emily Compagno on whether this is basically upends the entire robot car industry. That's after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Cars are supposed to stop traffic fatalities but now a bombshell. The first driverless robot car death in a public road evolving ridesharing company Uber. It's now suspending its robot car program after woman was struck and killed by one of its robot cars at 10 o'clock last night in Tempe, Arizona.

Attorney Emily Compagno, I mean, how worried are you about robot cars killing people? We thought they were supposed to stop traffic fatalities.

EMILY COMPAGNO, ATTORNEY: Right. And it's hard because in this field which is noble one death is one death too many but in the larger picture we see over -- we see up to 50 million disabled and injury results from car crashes a year and millions death, right, it's the highest -- it's the highest cause of death in the country.

But again, the argument for autonomous vehicle in part is that it's supposed to be safer because it removes that human element. But in situations like this is it possible that the human element the ability to be malleable and to react to things that that ultimately what would render an autonomous vehicle safer.

MACDONALD: Yes.

COMPAGNO: So it kind of begs a larger question, right? But what we're seeing this play out is going to be in a regulatory field. The reason that Arizona has so many tech companies playing in that field now it's because they've said they taking an accommodating approach to not regulate the autonomous riding field there.

MACDONALD: All right. You know, Emily, I hear what you're saying. We hear so many glowing statements about how great robot cars are going to be. But you know what's not being discussed, Emily, is this. Robot cars have been found to not properly read highway signs if those highway signs have been slightly altered. They don't know how to read it. And some of these were about cars don't even network and talk to other robot cars.

That's the big deal for Apple. Apple can have its own Apple closed system in these cars. So the thing is, Emily, we still haven't figured out who is going to be liable for robot car death. Is it companies like Uber or the software?

COMPAGNO: Right. Well, in every case it's going to be a different analysis as to who or what is responsible, right? So we saw in a large accident earlier that didn't involve a fatality that human driver that was in the autonomous vehicle he was ultimately held responsible because of that.

In another major crash it was the other driver of the car that T-bone the autonomous driving vehicle. And I think the larger answer to your question is that this is why test phase is so important. This is why we're not ready to hit the road yet. This is why kind of a phase physical area for these cars to be tested is so crucial.

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: Right. Bingo.

COMPAGNO: Because otherwise of course now we'll see more fatalities.

MACDONALD: You just nailed it. That's the thing, Emily. Because this is like a -- we're just at the beginning stages of this and now we have a woman killed by a robot car, right? I mean, this is a big deal.

COMPAGNO: Yes. And note that just next month or in April, California has maintained that they will now allow test writing of these autonomous vehicles without the human driver inside, right? Up until now it's just been Arizona. So that's something that we're going to see now a huge test zone there, that's a physical fight at the Silicon Valley, right. So we'll see a lot more.

MACDONALD: Emily, we need you back on. We love having you on to break it all down and drill into this. You're terrific. Please come back on the show. Good to see you.

(CROSSTALK)

COMPAGNO: Thank you.

MACDONALD: More after the break. Don't go away.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Breaking news on the Facebook data mining breach. Cambridge Analytica they're accused of abusing the Facebook data of potentially millions of Facebook users. Now Great Britain wants to seek a warrant to get into the computer servers of that data mining firm Cambridge Analytica.

We're going to stay on that story for you tomorrow. Mondays are big night on Fox Business. Tune to two new episodes of Strange Inheritance tonight at 9 p.m. Eastern Time.

Thank you so much for watching. Charles Payne here now with Making Money. Take it away, Charles.

END

urn:contentItem:5WF7-BYG1-DY0W-43F1-00000-00Facebook Is In The Crosshairs Right Now For The Alleged Misuse Of Information, Fifty Million Facebook Data Were Harvested Without Their Permission; Lawmakers Are Demanding An Investigation of Facebook; Tech Stocks Are Down Today As It Also Sympathizes With Facebook's Decline; E.U. Also Threatened To Slap A Whopping 3 Percent Tax On All U.S. Tech Company Sales As Well; Lawmakers On Both Sides Of The Aisle Have Reacted On The Firing Of FBI Deputy Director Andrew Mccabe; Los Alamitos County In Southern California Is Standing Up, Saying They Want To Opt Out Of California Sanctuary Laws That Restrict Cooperation Between Local Police And Federal Immigration; Uber Pulls Out Its Program From Self-Driving Vehicle After a Woman Died Last Night When a Robot Car Struck and Killed Her in Tempe, Arizona; Al Sharpton's National Action Network, Black Lives Matter, and the New Black Panther Party are Organizing a Protest in Support of and in Defense of Louis Farrakhan; Hillary Clinton Posted on Facebook a Lengthy Non-Apology Statement Trying to Defend Her Controversial Comments About the Trump Voters and Why She Lost the Race2018-03-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:46:16ZLexisNexisFacebook Is In The Crosshairs Right Now For The Alleged Misuse Of Information, Fifty Million Facebook Data Were Harvested Without Their Permission; Lawmakers Are Demanding An Investigation of Facebook; Tech Stocks Are Down Today As It Also Sympathizes With Facebook's Decline; E.U. Also Threatened To Slap A Whopping 3 Percent Tax On All U.S. Tech Company Sales As Well; Lawmakers On Both Sides Of The Aisle Have Reacted On The Firing Of FBI Deputy Director Andrew Mccabe; Los Alamitos County In Southern California Is Standing Up, Saying They Want To Opt Out Of California Sanctuary Laws That Restrict Cooperation Between Local Police And Federal Immigration; Uber Pulls Out Its Program From Self-Driving Vehicle After a Woman Died Last Night When a Robot Car Struck and Killed Her in Tempe, Arizona; Al Sharpton's National Action Network, Black Lives Matter, and the New Black Panther Party are Organizing a Protest in Support of and in Defense of Louis Farrakhan; Hillary Clinton Posted on Facebook a Lengthy Non-Apology Statement Trying to Defend Her Controversial Comments About the Trump Voters and Why She Lost the RaceLanhamFULL TEXT

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

NEIL CAVUTO, FOX NEWS HOST: Have you been seeing what's going on with Facebook. This industry darling led the market up last year and through much of this year quite a different take today.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Cambridge Analytica was able to can collect the data from 50 million people's profiles without permission. In the U.S., in Europe, in the U.K. are calling for investigations Facebook is in the crosshairs.

GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS REPORTER: Social media companies are trading lower today. I guess in sympathy. Twitter, Snap, Google all lower.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: People are starting to grow tired of social media.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes, yes.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Facebook basically can't be escape. This is something that as far --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Everybody in their mother now saying we are going to investigate.

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX NEWS HOST: Facebook privacy hitting markets really hard today. Facebook having its worst day in five and half years. The Dow also are down nearly 500 points at session lows at tech is drag down in sympathy. The NASDAQ slid nearly 2 percent. Facebook dragging tech stock lower.

This, after reports that the personal Facebook data of an estimated 50 million people were harvested without their permission for political ad. You will not believe what we found that Facebook has on you. One hundred separate bits of information. We're going to show you what Facebook is collecting about you. E.U. also threatening a whopping 3 percent tax on tech company sales as well.

And this now breaking. The Connecticut Attorney General's office is initiating an inquiry into Facebook data policy after that report.

Also tonight, could Andrew McCabe, the fired former FBI deputy director incriminate the fired FBI James Comey, not just release to the media but for also lying to Congress. We got the sound and the debate coming up. We're on it.

And a tiny California town now defiantly fighting back against California sanctuary policy, saying it will instead follow their sworn oath to defend the Constitution and uphold immigration laws. It's the City of Los Alamitos it's voted tonight to not be a sanctuary city. It faces the threat of lawsuits in California condemnation as well. The mayor of that town here to talk about the fight.

Plus, driverless robot cars, now they were supposed to reduce traffic fatalities by eliminating human error. But now a robot car from ridesharing company Uber has killed a pedestrian in Arizona. It happened last night. So what will happen to the robot revolution? That's now in the works of a slew of auto companies like Tesla, G.M. Ford and also Silicon Valley. We're bringing an expert to weigh in.

Tonight, an all-guest lineup. Economist Ben Stein, former special assistant to President Trump, Marc Lotter, legal eagle Harvard Law professor Alan Dershowitz, the Federalist Britt McHenry, all here all tonight.

Politics, money, we got you covered. I'm Elizabeth McDonald. Risk and Reward starts right now.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARK ZUCKERBERG, CEO, FACEBOOK: I wish I could tell you that we're going to be able to stop all interference but that just wouldn't be realistic. There will always be bad actors in the world and we can't prevent all governments from all interference. But we can make it harder. We can make it much harder and that's what we're going to focus on doing.

We won't catch everyone immediately but we can make it harder to try to determine (Ph).

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: The Dow down 335 points closing to that 24,610. The NASDAQ taking hits, that was down as well. Facebook stocks ending more than 6 percent down or 12 points lower after suspending a political analysis firm Cambridge Analytics after reports that the research firm harvested personal Facebook data on 270,000 Facebook users without their permission.

Now you can't Facebook friends and family. The breach may affect an estimated 50 million people. It's being Facebook Equifax breach. The research firm also reportedly told Facebook it did delete the user info when it did not. Pretty scary stuff.

There's actually a really long list of things that Facebook knows about you. We counted a hundred different things. For example, where you live, your age, your education, income, net worth, your wedding anniversary birthday whether you recently moved.

If you're in a long-distance relationship, whether you are conservative or liberal, whether you like would you're likely to buy your next car, how many workers your company has, whether you carry a credit card balance. The time of year your household shops and the most types of vacations you take, the pets you have, and so on, and so on, and so on, more and more and more.

But first, Lori Rothman on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange on the market drop after reports of this privacy breach at Facebook. You know, Lori, Facebook faces a threat of federal fines. The tech sector also dropping after the E.U. threaten to slap U.S. tech companies with a 3 percent tax of sales and revenues. Wow, Lori.

LORI ROTHMAN, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: One, two punch against the tech sector today and that just drag down the broad market. We had the Dow closing down 335 points today, believe it or not that's well, well more than a hundred points off the session low for the Dow. Down now negative temperature territory for 2018.

The S&P and the NASDAQ didn't fare much better. The NASDAQ was the worst in the benchmark three but it's still holding up for the year. There you see on your screen the NASDAQ fell 137 points blame Facebook.

But here is the thing that's got everyone here on Wall Street thinking. If Facebook is misusing customer data, user data, well, all of these tech companies use our data. They mine our data. We plug our data in. How do they get it, what do they do with it when they have it. And really how do they protect every day users.

So, a lot of the big tech company CEO's have been called upon by both Democrats and Republicans to testify about that. And then you mention this potential tax 3 percent by the E.U. on the tech company revenue.

So the good times may be over for tech. That was the thinking and the concern today on Wall Street, obviously nothing for sure on that front but any news of that degree again. Again, a one-two punch. The Facebook news and then the tax. My goodness. You're going to have some trouble.

And then of course you can talk about the ongoing trade and tariff controversy as well. So we did have a broad base rally, it wasn't just technology. All 10 S&P sectors were in the red today.

We do want to bring you up-to-date on some mergers, merger Monday. Well, actually this one in particular is going nowhere. I'm talking about AT&T and Time Warner shares both down in excess of 1 percent. AT&T tried today to get a judge to throw out evidence. It seems to show its $85 billion acquisition of Time Warner is bad for consumers and competition.

Now the Justice Department as you know did file a lawsuit back in November to stop this combination opening arguments in this case are still scheduled to begin on Wednesday. We're following it. Liz, back to you.

MACDONALD: Good to see you, Lori. Thank you so much.

ROTHMAN: Thank you.

MACDONALD: Now this firm that's denying claims of abusing and have taking without consent the data of millions of Facebook users. That's called Cambridge Analytics. This as Facebook hired a digital forensic firm to do an audit of Cambridge Analytica systems.

Politicians now pressuring Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg for answers on what's going on. The word is Mark Zuckerberg may have to testify before Congress. Remember he has political leanings.

MCHENRY: Thank you.

MACDONALD: Breaking news. Washington Post reporting that President Trump is preparing by this Friday to hit China with tariffs on $60 billion worth of goods that would double the what was earlier thought to be 30 billion, now it's going to 60 billion. It could be 100 different types of products hit with tariffs by this Friday.

This amid the escalation of trade tensions is going to four anonymous senior administration officials. We're staying on that story for you.

Now it appears to be the first robot car death on a public road. Ridesharing company Uber stopping its self-driving car program after a woman in Arizona was struck and killed by one of its robot vehicle.

Attorney Emily Compagno on whether this is basically upends the entire robot car industry. That's after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Cars are supposed to stop traffic fatalities but now a bombshell. The first driverless robot car death in a public road evolving ridesharing company Uber. It's now suspending its robot car program after woman was struck and killed by one of its robot cars at 10 o'clock last night in Tempe, Arizona.

Attorney Emily Compagno, I mean, how worried are you about robot cars killing people? We thought they were supposed to stop traffic fatalities.

EMILY COMPAGNO, ATTORNEY: Right. And it's hard because in this field which is noble one death is one death too many but in the larger picture we see over -- we see up to 50 million disabled and injury results from car crashes a year and millions death, right, it's the highest -- it's the highest cause of death in the country.

But again, the argument for autonomous vehicle in part is that it's supposed to be safer because it removes that human element. But in situations like this is it possible that the human element the ability to be malleable and to react to things that that ultimately what would render an autonomous vehicle safer.

MACDONALD: Yes.

COMPAGNO: So it kind of begs a larger question, right? But what we're seeing this play out is going to be in a regulatory field. The reason that Arizona has so many tech companies playing in that field now it's because they've said they taking an accommodating approach to not regulate the autonomous riding field there.

MACDONALD: All right. You know, Emily, I hear what you're saying. We hear so many glowing statements about how great robot cars are going to be. But you know what's not being discussed, Emily, is this. Robot cars have been found to not properly read highway signs if those highway signs have been slightly altered. They don't know how to read it. And some of these were about cars don't even network and talk to other robot cars.

That's the big deal for Apple. Apple can have its own Apple closed system in these cars. So the thing is, Emily, we still haven't figured out who is going to be liable for robot car death. Is it companies like Uber or the software?

COMPAGNO: Right. Well, in every case it's going to be a different analysis as to who or what is responsible, right? So we saw in a large accident earlier that didn't involve a fatality that human driver that was in the autonomous vehicle he was ultimately held responsible because of that.

In another major crash it was the other driver of the car that T-bone the autonomous driving vehicle. And I think the larger answer to your question is that this is why test phase is so important. This is why we're not ready to hit the road yet. This is why kind of a phase physical area for these cars to be tested is so crucial.

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: Right. Bingo.

COMPAGNO: Because otherwise of course now we'll see more fatalities.

MACDONALD: You just nailed it. That's the thing, Emily. Because this is like a -- we're just at the beginning stages of this and now we have a woman killed by a robot car, right? I mean, this is a big deal.

COMPAGNO: Yes. And note that just next month or in April, California has maintained that they will now allow test writing of these autonomous vehicles without the human driver inside, right? Up until now it's just been Arizona. So that's something that we're going to see now a huge test zone there, that's a physical fight at the Silicon Valley, right. So we'll see a lot more.

MACDONALD: Emily, we need you back on. We love having you on to break it all down and drill into this. You're terrific. Please come back on the show. Good to see you.

(CROSSTALK)

COMPAGNO: Thank you.

MACDONALD: More after the break. Don't go away.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Breaking news on the Facebook data mining breach. Cambridge Analytica they're accused of abusing the Facebook data of potentially millions of Facebook users. Now Great Britain wants to seek a warrant to get into the computer servers of that data mining firm Cambridge Analytica.

We're going to stay on that story for you tomorrow. Mondays are big night on Fox Business. Tune to two new episodes of Strange Inheritance tonight at 9 p.m. Eastern Time.

Thank you so much for watching. Charles Payne here now with Making Money. Take it away, Charles.

END
